In the old days, before this hydraulic machinery, miners had to dig through this rock-hard earth by hand, one hole at a time.
The holes were so narrow you could barely move your arms, and you were breathing in fine dust all day, in the blazing heat.

It was one of the dirtiest, most miserable jobs in the world, and a miner could go an entire year without finding a single opal.
You read that right. They had to dig hole after hole after hole until they found something; or not.

While serving as a police officer in the region from 1996 to 2004 I mined opal in my spare time.

Gadassi became a valued and trusted friend and mentor who would no doubt remember my close friend, police colleague and mining mate and I as George and Mick.

As you no doubt learned for yourself from his remarks like 'yeah or what I put the rope there for?'

Gadassi's sense of humor is as dry as an outback summer and his intense, almost limitless energy is analogous to the explosives he uses to mine.

Have no doubt that Gadassi can swarm up a safety rope so fast he virtually pops out of a shaft like a cork.

On one occasion while prospecting old claims his generator broke down so Gadassi climbed a regular shaft freehand without the benefit of a safety rope.

When he did so that time he startled the heck out of Judy who was waiting at the top of the shaft he originally went down when he walked up behind her.

He is kind, generous, wise in the ways of life and men, as sharp as a razor blade and tough as the chisel on a jackhammer (as a young man he was a sergeant in the Greek army).

My mate George and I enjoyed the hospitality of Gadassi and his late wife Judie at their home in Coober Pedy on numerous occasions.

Gadassi helped George and I in many ways from advice on mining from safety to geology and guiding us with regard to pegging a claim. (The shaft on that one was 100 feet deep)

He also classed the occasional bit of opal for us and all the while generously imparted his almost limitless knowledge and understanding of all things related to opal.

You could not have had a better guide and mentor during your stay in Coober Pedy than Gadassi, he is a bit of a local legend among people who know gem quality in men when they encounter it.

(He wasn't joking about the ladies either and I assure you it is a subject he takes seriously indeed.)

If he is your friend, be certain that it is for life.

Ok, so i'm gonna share a little story of my own here that mirrors this video. I went on holiday to Turkey and they had horse rides. I had never ridden a horse in my life. Me and my SO at the time go to this guys place and it looks like some random guy that just so happens to have some horses, no tourist stuff, he just has horses. So we get on the horses, no reigns just a peg on the saddle. 5 minutes later with only 5 minutes experience of riding a horse he says "now, we gallop". The horse takes off and i'm thinking "why did I trust this guy, he's crazy". After not dying for about 20 minutes on and off  we stop at a local cafe. He tells my SO, your horse is 'the crazy horse'!  We finish coffee and a bite and head back, at a gallop. Of course, i'm on the 'crazy' horse now. and it was crazy..Galloping and then coming to a full stop to eat some random leaf and taking off again. We got back to his house safe and sound if not a little shook up. I see the same experience here. Turks be crazy, but crazy fun. looking back,  I wouldn't trade that experience for anything.  Turkish people definitely believe in learning by doing and I am OK with that, now.

When I was in college, I loved the lectures and learning, but the exams (especially the finals) always felt like the Sword of Damocles hanging over me.  I majored in Wildlife Management (I was a Park Ranger), but I've always had an interest in science, engineering and technology, and now that I'm retired I have often thought about taking a class here and there for fun, but I want the knowledge without the formal setting of a classroom and without the tests.  I don't want or need to do it for the sheepskin or a bunch of letters after my name.  The Great Courses Plus offers a way to expand your knowledge on a subject that interests you, and you can do it at home - and don't have to worry about a test. Feedback on the Sponsor: The Great Courses
In short - I do not recommend.
I don't doubt these courses are good, well edited, with substantive content and quality production. But the issue that I have is this:

* Rather than pay-per-course, it requires a subscription/membership, with your billing information on an automatic renewal...which we all know what that means. Extra work to have to cancel.
*I could not find a catalog of courses/ topics to survey prior to being required to sign up for a membership - no way to know if there's enough interesting content/courses for my interests.
* Get ready for sticker shock! It's hella expensive, (particularly in light that there's so much free content already available online!)
* Only available as a streaming-only service, mobile apps require a wireless connection.
* I think the term 'courses' can be misleading. Yes, the content is prepared & delivered as a conventional 'course', but you don't actually earn any formal credit/hours from completing the course. This is purely for the joy of learning.
* Lacks course materials and closed captioning at launch.
* In the end, this company is for profit, and although you gain knowledge and learn...this is exactly what the internet (which is free) already provides in a very robust way. YouTube alone is a platform with millions of 'courses' and educational/knowledge sharing videos. Also consider, the vast array of TedTalks, Khan Academy, and dozens of other MOOCs (massive online open courses). I don't think this company is offering anything uniquely special or out-of-the-box, but rather monetizing on content that they prepare and package in their own brand...but essentially the content is free elsewhere!

But hey, for the avid learner, in the market for paid subscription to a catalog of courses...sure, the Great Courses is an option. To each his own.

Hey Destin, feedback on your new sponsor. I could not get myself to do the free trial. My reason? I need to input billing information to do so. I have expendable income but not much of it. Naturally, I was happy to take advantage of a free month of learning during the holiday season. However, Great Courses wants me to input my billing info to do so.

I know you might say "Oh just do it and cancel it immediately so youre not billed", great, but I read the fine print on the sign up page, it says that during the trial period, if you cancel, your services end. Basically they are only willing to give me this trial so long as they have my billing info. They're betting on me forgetting to cancel and getting charged for a month. "So set a reminder on your phone or something" Why? It is clear to me they want to make that difficult for me, obviously I am not their target and they are not terribly excited about me using their services at all.

This is something I do not appreciate in a business. While I can spare 20 bucks easily, I will not be sparing it to this company and I will not be doing the monthly trial to make sure that I do not. I understand they have to make money and theyre particularly interested in giving these trials to people who will actually consider staying subscribed, but where I come from, a free trial doesn't require a form of payment.

I will say this for any Great Courses representatives, the only thing that will cause me to remember your service a few years down the road is me getting a free trial right now. So, in my opinion, that was a stupid move on your part. I will forget your service, had you given me the trial regardless, this would probably not have been the case. Plus, I definitely won't be bringing you up in any conversations because you've given me nothing to talk about. If youre scared of not making money off of me, what could possibly be the harm in giving me the trial? It's not going to change how much money you make off of me, plus or minus.

Hey Destin, you seem like a guy who cares about the details so I make this comment assuming you'll appreciate it and not take it as being condescending.
Opals are not rocks but are mineraloids. Basically you can think of this as a material consisting of any number of different elements in any number of specific arrangements, that is naturally occurring but lacks a crystal structure (if it did have a definite crystalline structure opal would be considered a mineral). A rock is composed of many different types of minerals (e.g. A generic granite might be composed of minerals such as quartz, feldspars, and say hornblende).
I hope this helps. I love your videos, rock on.

#FYI

You should go to the Royal Peacock mines in Virgin Valley, Nevada, where the public can mine/sort for precious opal here in the U.S. I've never gone, but I wanted to go. I only live a couple states over, anyways. I might do when they open up in mid May next year (they're closed for the season now). I've cut a lot of opal though, sourced from Australia, Ethiopia, Honduras, Brazil and even Canada. American material is very expensive though, so I've never worked with it before. It would be fun to find a couple pieces to cut, just to add to my collection. But it is interesting working with different material from around the world and finding so much beauty hidden in the rough. Glad you found a friendly miner to show you the ropes =)

As for advertising, I watched the advert because I liked the video, but I'll note that many colleges and universities are offering free online course material, although you have to pay to be instructed/tested/vetted, and most of the course material I've seen is only literary, not video instruction. But it's a good idea, in any case. It would be nice if the first year of college was paid by the government, just to help boot-strap people into higher education without there being a lot of risk involved.
